lg.l: What are our Councillors Councillors. Members of the Provincial Council of the Marlborough region, in the South Island of Aoteroa New Zealand. doing,
Brothers, the whole day long,
While the floods Floods. The settlement of Blenheim had been devastated by a flood in February 1868. bring wreck and ruin
With a power fierce and strong?
Where’s the cash they were going to borrow,
To stop the overflow?
Friend John, with a look of sorrow,
Says “Hang me, if I know;”
But I would very much rather
Dam the overflow.
A draught of water’s pleasant
When you are very dry,
And pleasant is the purling brook
That murmurs gently by;
But oh, these dirty waters,
So drumlie Drumlie. Turbid, murky. and so brown,
They’re neither sweet nor pleasant
That inundate the town.
The poet Poet. The poem quotes from William Shakespeare’s A Midsummer Night’s Dream, Act 2 scene 1. said, “I know a bank
Whereon the wild thyme grows,”
And I, too, know another bank
O’er which the Opawa Opawa. The Ōpaoa River, formerly known as the Opawa River, flows through Blenheim. flows.

The Councillors round King Canute’s King Canute. Cnut the Great, King of England in the 11th century, was reputed to have ordered the tide not to come in as a demonstration of his political power. chair
Bade him keep the wild waves back;
I wish the Councillors round our Mayor
Would keep the river in its track.
Oh say, Lord Henry, Lord Henry. Henry Dodson was mayor of Blenheim, 1870-71, after previously being a member of the Marlborough Provincial Council. where's the cash
You all were going to borrow?
Or shall the flood I moan to-day
Be free to return to-morrow?
